values:
Hello Live Journal!  I know it's been a while ...you miss me?

Well I'm back and better than ever!  As of today, I am a proud new owner of my own web domain!

(drumroll please!)

www.robinrothman.com!!!   (minus the exclamation points)

After much technical support and encouragement from Sean, I have set to work on my very first and very own "home on the interne(s)t.  (It's a bird theme) - it seemed the logical way to go since after all my name is Robin, like the bird and my parents and a few select friends have called me "bird" for many many years.

So why not, right?

Here's a glimpse of what's up there right now...




pretty friggin' sweet, eh? ...it's a nest!
with Robin eggs in it!

...get it?

Anyway, each egg is going to be a link to a page on my site.  I've got some more images to complete but the eggs and the nest were among the biggest challenges.  All in all I'm pretty happy with how things are shaping up.  (sigh) I feel like a proud mama bird waiting for her chicks to hatch.

In keeping with the theme of my website I am here to announce the official launch date ...or if you will, "hatch date" of my website...

(another drumroll please...)

3/21/08!    ...The first day of Spring!

www.robinrothman.com will be "taking flight" with more bird puns than you can shake a tail feather at.  Well, I suppose I'd better get back to incubating my eggs.  Until then!

So I'm Jewish.  As such, I never had a  Christmas tree growing up.  There were some members of my tribe who had what they called a "Hanukkah Bush." There really is no such thing as a "Hanukkah Bush."  Evergreens don't grow in Isreal where the miracle of the oil lasting 8 days and 8 nights happened lo those many years ago!  No.  A Hanukkah Bush is merely 20th century invention adopted some 30 plus years ago by a segment of American reform Jews to help ease the pain of their children who felt left out in the predominantly Chrisitan neighborhoods.

I say, let's call a spade a spade and a Christmas Tree a Christmas Tree.  But, in the end - what do I care, really?  I support a person's right to celebrate what they want, how they want, wherever they want. So, Hanukkah Bush it up people!  L'chaim!

Anyway, I like Christmas.  and I like Christmas trees, and this year, thanks to Sean, I felt like I had one of my very own. 

Unfortunately Sean got stuck doing the grunt work of going out and getting the tree all by himself.  I would have liked to have had a hand in the tree-purchasing process.  To me, the process of picking out and purchasing the tree is half the fun.  You both go out to a tree lot early in the morning before the holiday rush and  search and search for the perfect little tree.  Finally it calls out to you, just like in National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation.  Then one of you stands guard while the other goes to haggle a reasonable price with the tree guy.  Finally, a deal is struck and the two of you march your perfect tree home just like they do in that Christmastime montage scene in When Harry Met Sally.

ahh Christmas...

Well, even though I didn't get to play out my tree-buying fantasy in real life, it didn't take away from the fun of having my first tree.  The whole point of getting the tree was to throw a tree-trimming party at Sean's for those who didn't have anywhere else to be the weekend leading up to Christmas.  Sean had purchased all manner of bare [Christmas] balls - (tee hee) , glitter paints, glue and a myriad of other merry-making materials, and his guests were charged with the happy task of decorating  their very own [Christmas] balls...(tee hee again) - and trimming the tree with them.  Pretty adora-ball if you ask me!

Here are some photos from the evening...


My very first Christmas Tree!!!!  (naked)




Sean playing host!



Moi "hamming it up" for the camera!  (ba doom ching!)



decoration station!




sexy was brought back that night ...and then upon seeing these crazy dance moves, it got scared and ran away



Oh!  Lookout!  Here's me trimming the tree!



My Jewish snowman "Schneiman":-)




an origami paper decoupage ornament - (or as Sean called it, "Dickpache")




and finally...the finished product...
TAH DAH!



And so this little Jewish girl finally got her Chrismukkah wish of having her very own Christmas Tree. 
...
...
...
The very next morning, I was sitting on the couch talking to my mom and doing some cleaning up from what was left behind as a result of the previous night's festivities when all of a sudden

BOOM!

There arose such a clatter - I rose from my seat to see what was the matter. 
The christmas tree that we had all just decorated with care,
fell on its side and caught me unaware!

I shrieked out "Oh NO!"
and my mom yelled, "What happened?!"
"The tree just fell down,
what if the ornaments are flattened?"
"Stay calm," said my mother,
"I'm sure there's something you can do."
"Maybe it's all my fault,
after all, I'm a Jew."

"Nonsense!" said my mother.
"go on and rescue that tree!"
So I picked it up with all of my might
and it looked as happy as could be.
The ornaments were still in tact
and they looked just as fantastic.
Fortunately for me, every single one,
was only made out of plastic.

Finally all was back under control
That the tree had come down,
hardly anyone would know.
I slumped back on the couch
and breathed out a long sigh
"Merry Christmas to all,
and to all a good... a good...
uh...
a good...
BYE!"

The Magnet Theater has become a home away from home for me in many respects.  I always look forward to Magnet parties because they always provide the perfect opportunity to hang out with old friends and meet and make some new ones as well.  Looking back on last year, I realized that it was at the Magnet Christmas Party of 2006, where I met and made a particularly special new friend for the very first time...  :-)

Magnet Holiday Party 2006...





What a difference a year makes...

This is what followed the big reveal at the Mag...  can't beat it!



"I Got You Babe"



um...I don't remember what they were singing here, but I'm sure it was manly :-)


"In the Ghetto"

PIZZA MONTH 2007 - Day 31 aka Halloween!!!

This is MY New York!

I've lived in the city for almost 5 years now, and up until this point never took the time to walk over the Brooklyn Bridge which, in my humble opinion, is the most BEAUTIFUL bridge in the whole wide...world!

I met with Sean and Ruby and Mike Leigh for some of the best coal-fired brick oven pizza one could wish for...


...and then we topped off our meal with a lovely sunset walk across the bridge...



 ahhhh... another I LOVE NEW YORK moment...



lookout!  that's Bandito Sean up ahead...


I held my phone out over the traffic below to capture this beauty


Lower Manhattan


I think Lady Liberty is in there - maybe just off to the left...


Look at those sky scrapers against that sky!!!



...another pic from Sean's album.  I love the way he managed to perfectly frame the ESB within the Brooklyn Bridge - a New York landmark within a landmark!





-THE END-

Hey Live Journal - believe it or not this Friday is my 10 Year High School Reunion.  That's right, can I get an amen?!?  I have been out of high school for over 10 YEARS!!!  YIKES!!!

Sheesh!  Where has the time gone?  There's nothing like a reunion to kick your brain into gear about what you've done with the past 10 years of your life.  What have I done? Have I done enough? too much?  too little? I don't want to make comparisons to my fellow classmates at this reunion thing.   I just want to reunite and reminisce. 

As I write this entry - there is one moment in particular from high school that jumps out at me...

It was our senior year when we "Ruled the School" and my best friend Blayne decided to throw a last-minute Halloween party at her house.  Our whole gang was going to be there - man we had such great parties back then!  I miss those parties! 
Anyway, I dressed up in my mother's wedding gown as a dead bride - (sadly, I had no groom at the time) and my friends sorta dressed up too - but there was no competing with what I had managed to whip up in an afternoon. :-)  We were all  sitting around in her living room feeling like cool seniors when suddenly our friend Josh piped up. "Wow guys, just think 10 years from now we'll be sitting around at our High School Reunion!  Where do you think we'll all be in 10 years?" 
The room went silent.  Nice buzz kill Josh!  I remember looking around at my friends and thinking: first of all -  that's a good fucking question!  but second of all:  I need to remember this moment.  I need to remember my friends right now the way they are because some day this will all be gone.  In 10 years who knows if we'll even be talking to each other any more.  In 10 years things will be different...we'll be different! 
At the time it made me kind of sad and nostalgic for something that I hadn't yet lost but inevitably knew I would. 

I love that memory of my friends. 

I suppose that some people might find all of this a bit depressing - but I don't.  Fortunately for me, I feel like life began after high school.  All the same I think it will be nice to see some old friends and reminisce about the olden days at GWHS.  But there is still that part of me that would rather not go at all and remember them the way they were when we were 17 that Halloween.

Hey Live Journal - apparently I've made the cover of TIME Magazine.  or rather an illustrated version of me has made the cover of TIME Magazine. 

Well, let's be frank - it's not really me at all - but someone who sort of looks like me.  A friend and fellow improviser approached me the other night with a copy of the magazine when a bunch of us were all hanging out at the bar.  Even though most of us had been drinking throughout the night there was no denying that the girl on the cover bore a rather striking resemblance to me.

well actually - maybe it was due to the fact that we were drinking that made us think the picture looked like me to begin with.
I dunno, you be the judge.

Something unexpected and incredibly beautiful happened in the skies over Manhattan today, Live Journal.  At approximately 6pm immediately following a rain shower, the clouds parted, the sun glistened against the buildings and a rainbow appeared...





I almost didn't believe my own eyes.  Can you see it?  I snapped a few photos of it with my measly cell phone camera.  They definitely don't due this natural phenomenon any justice - but it was worth a shot.



Do you see how the rainbow looks like it's shooting right out of the top of that building?  Pretty cool, eh?



I looked up and saw that the rainbow stretched clear across the sky over Manhattan in an enormous arc.  Unfortunately the arc had faded by the time I got my phone to take the pictures.  You can kind of see the other end of the rainbow which ended up behind this building.



Preeeettyyyyy...

Oh, and I wasn't the only one who caught a glimpse of the rainbow and posted pictures about it...



This fellow blogger obviously captured it on a much higher resolution camera than I.



What a sight!  I just can't get over it!  Just when you thought New York couldn't get any better...it goes and gets rainbows!!!

As you know Live Journal, I made my third and what was to be final attempt at auditioning for American Idol '07 this past August.  I had taken a bunch of pictures on my cell phone and I finally downloaded them onto my computer: so I thought why not add a pictorial summary of my experience as well?

Here goes!

SATURDAY, August 25 - REGISTRATION BEGINS

Saturday morning was sign-up and registration day for all American Idol hopefuls.  The registration began at approximately 5:30am (even thought the website had clearly stated that they wouldn't be admitting anyone into the stadium before 6am) and continued until 8am on Monday, 8/27 (Audition Day.)

Fortunately for me, the wait ended up not being too long after all.  It was a good thing too because I am NOT a morning person and I was in a bit of a frazzled state having missed my alarm and woken up an hour later than I had intended (5:30am instead of 4:30am.)  I raced down to the Wachovia stadium like a bat out of hell without incident, but upon approaching the entrance to the parking lot, then some punk rear-ended me.  I kinda flipped out on him because at first I thought he was trying to leave the scene of the crime.  Like I said, I am NOT a morning person and to top it off, I was driving my dad's semi-brand new car. 

I wasn't in my finest form that morning.  I kinda went crazy Philly bitch on his ass: 
"Get the fuck out of your car!" I screamed.
"Okay, okay!" said Punky McPunkerson. "I'm sorry, I'm really tired."
"Yeah, no kidding."
A lady cop saw the commotion and approached reluctantly. 

I ran around to the back of my dad's car to assess the damage.  A small scrape and chip to the plastic bumper had resulted from the collision.  fuck.

"You're gonna have to pull over to the side of the road if you want to file a report." said lady cop.
"Fuck it." I got back into the car in a huff and pulled into the lot.  I just wanted to get this crap over with.

Within the next 20 minutes my dad's newly damaged car was parked and my wallet was $11 lighter (thank you event parking.)  I then immediately proceeded (meaning ran like a crazy person) to line up for registration. 

I was in front of all of these people...


I was behind all of these people...


By approximately 7am, I was all ticketed and braceleted. 



MISSION ACCOMPLISHED!  I wasn't to return until between 5 and 6am on Monday morning for the BIG DAY - soon to be known as the day that I, Robin Rothman would become a STAR!!!


MONDAY, August 27th - THE BIG DAY


6ish am - My slow but steady approach to the Wachovia Center...traffic and parking, as expected was a real beeotch.


I ended up parking in the Citizens Bank Park lot across from the Wachovia Center.  Citizens Bank Park is the home of the Phillies. GO PHILLIES! 



(Since I am a huge Phillies fan, and I had previously auditioned in cities and sports arenas of teams which have defeated Philadelphia sports teams - i.e. Gillette Stadium home of the Patriots who defeated the Eagled in SB XXXIX - I decided to take this as a good omen for the day.)  It was nice to finally be auditioning in my home town.


Once again, as with Saturday morning, by approximately 6:30am I was parked and $11 poorer.  (That event parking system is really quite a racket!)

I decided to chill in the car for a bit longer before lining up to be admitted into the Wachovia Center.  I was surprisingly much more calm than I had been on Saturday morning.  I think that getting a good spot in the registration line is the most important thing of all.  The ticket you receive upon registering is what determines the order in which you will be seen on the day of the audition, and if you don't want to spend an entire day waiting around to be seen, best to get there bright and early. 

That said - there's no point in hurrying into line on the day of the audition, unless you really want to try your luck at getting on camera in one of those sweeping crowd shots you always see at the opening of the show.  Otherwise, once you're registered with your ticket and bracelet, the rest is all left up to fate (and some pretty darn good singin', of course.)

6:39am - The journey to stardom begins...

After a quick hair and make-up check and a few vocal warm-up exercises, I embark on my AI adventure...

My approach to the WC


(People...)



(People who need to sing for people...)



(are the Luckiest 13,000 people in the world!!!)

 
(...man, I hope so!)

6:45am - Sleepy time...

I could tell it was gonna be a little while until we were actually granted admission into the stadium.  I threw down a towel I found in the back seat of my dad's car and copped a sqat on a the warm concrete of the Wachovia parking lot.  I eventually ended up using my bag as a pillow, throwing my trusty pashmina over my head and actually managed to catch a few winks!  yeah, when I'm tired enough, I can sleep just about anywhere. 

(even surrounded by these people)


(and these folks too...)


One girl near me in line took the expression "Break a Leg!" a little too literally...

...I guess it's more like "BREG a Leg!"

8:45am - After a nice nappy nap with my fellow auditionees, PAs in golf carts begin to wind their way through the serpentine line and disperse information about what can and cannot be brought into the stadium. 
1. Only one water bottle per person - (it was explained to us that spare bottles can be used as weapons: keep one to drink from & deliver a crushing blow to the back of an innocent bystander's head. sure.)
2. No food
3. No blankets
4. No chairs
5. No hunting knives
6. No firearms
7. No Camping equipment
8. No suitcases
9. No large backpacks
10. No aerosole cans of hairspray
11. No glass
12. No kitchen sinks... the list goes on...

After we had all been given a good talking to, the PAs and security guards started leading us to the entrance in a calm and orderly fashion. 


The true meaning of a "Cattle Call"


(MMMMOOOOOOOOOOOOO!!!!!!!!!)


(MMMMMOOOOOOOOOOOO!!!!!)


(BAAAAAAHHHHH - hey!  who let a sheep in here?)


(aw maaaan... I shoulda made a poster :(  ...I have that same leopard-print halter too!  :)


are we fucking there yet???


getting closer...


...and closer...


almost there...


TIME OUT - check out all this trash!



crikey!



The PAs and security guards had put the fear of Simon Cowell in everyone and they were disposing of EVERYTHING you can imagine:  chairs, sleeping bags, water coolers, backpacks, crumb cake, parasoles...you name it!

9:ish am - At long last!!!


After a check of my ticket and a half-assed search of my $5 handbag by security (I managed to sneak in not only some food but TWO water bottles) - I was inside the stadium!!!

I took a quick look around, made a stop at the Ladies' and then headed to my seat - (aka, my place in line.)

9:30 am - I'm seated!

I'm in my seat and literally ready to rock n' roll.  I was quite happy to discover that I was very close to the front of the line.  I should be seen in no time!



...of course, by "in no time" I mean, after the production crew gets all of their jib shots for the opening sequence of the show, directs all 20,000 of us in singing "I Love Rock n' Roll", and screaming and shouting all kinds of other ridiculous AI mantras such as: "I'm the Next American Idol!" and "Philly is the Place to BE!!!" and "Lookout SIMON!" - list...goes...on...

10:00am - Crowd control

The director and AD (whom I recognized from years past) - started giving us their shpeil about how everything will work.  What and what not to do.  yadda, yadda, yadda...



We started doing all of the crap stated above.  Many people around me were over it before we had even gotten started (they'll never be AIs with that kind of attitude!)

I decided to say, "the hell with it" and despite my exhaustion just tried to have a good time...




Singin', "I LOVE ROCK n' ROLL - put another dime in the juke box BABY!  I Love Rock n' Roll, won't you take the time and dance with ME?"



After a few more takes it was revealed that there would be a surprise guest appearance by a top AI celeb!


the crew preparing for the mystery guest's entrance...

Who could it BE????


Why, it's none other than American Idol announcer RYAN SEACREST!!!
(pictured here as the tiny man in the beige shirt and black pants.  He's really not that much bigger in real life! aw...poor cute little Ryan Seacrest.)

Ryan was apparently hopping from town to town to shoot these stupid openings where he runs out onto each stadium floor announcing each audition city. 
"Ladies and Gentlemen, this is PHILADELPHIA!" 
and then we, the crowd, go wild! 

All the same, it was kinda nice to have Ryan there.  It was almost surrealy comforting to have this little pop culture icon do his bit and then say a few words of encouragement before being whisked away to his next big gig. 

In fact it was he who announced to us that there were approximately 13,000 registered auditionees in the stadium that day:  the largest turnout in American Idol history to date!  Now that's pretty impressive! 

11:30am - The show gets on the road!!!

At long last, after much ado - the auditions finally got underway.  Dozens of AI PAs swarmed the stadium floor and begin setting up a total of 16 audition booths.  They sure know how to hustle - a short time later it looked like this...



Almost immediately the PAs began lining up the prospective American Idols.  Once the judges were in place, the auditions were off and running!

The first groups to audition were the folks seated in the sections to the right of me (pictured below)...


In these sections alone, I'd estimate that there were about 1,000 people.  That gave me pleanty of time to kick back and relax before it was my time to shine!

12:00pm - Relax, go do it!

I watched the auditions for a bit.  The first groups sent to the audition tables looked more like calves being led to slaughter.  A good 20 minutes must have gone by before the first "winner" of the day was sent through to the next round. 

I should point out that at the American Idol auditions, there were only two types of people: Winners and non-Winners.  But NO LOSERS!!!  Winners would be sent on to compete in future rounds.  Non-Winners were thanked for their time and sent on their not-so-merry way.

What would I be today?  a WINNER or a NON... ugh, I didn't want to give it much more thought so I decided to take a breather.  One of the things I had really wanted to do this year was soak up more of the American Idol audition experience! - (also, I really needed to go to the bathroom.)

I was waiting in line for the Ladies' Room when I saw a crowd gathering in one corner of the hallway where they had set up American Idol Karaoke.  That's right, in case you hadn't been given ample opportunities to blow out your voice before your audition, here's one more!

The karaoke had subsided for the time being however, and I noticed some stage hands setting up some other equipment.  Now, I had heard a rumor on the radio that morning that Season Four AI finalist Constantine Maroulis was also scheduled to make an appearance at the Wachovia Center. 
                                                                                                                                                    You know...Him!

 






Well, I wasn't going to believe it 'til I had seen it. 

After all, why on earth would a pseudo-famous rock n' roll celebrity type want to bother with an appearance at these auditions?  Oh yeah, I suppose he's just gonna set up shop in the middle of a hallway in the Wachovia Center on a miniature stage the size of a soapbox that's sponsored by Garnier Fructis hair care prodicts just so he can perform a few of his self-produced songs from his self-produced album on his self-produced indie record label...

oh. wait a minute...



...aw geez.



Sure enough, there he was - singin' his silly songs and toting his wares like a homeless person on the streets of New York - or er, Philadelphia.  (yeah, they have that sort of thing in Philly too.) 

actually, to tell you the truth he rather looked like a homeless person...

hopefully someone from Garnier Fructis hooked him up with some samples.  Yikes!

Well, I guess it just goes to show you that not everybody has it made in the shade after American Idol fame.  and I think that Constantine's main purpose of being there that day was to remind all of us of that immutable truth.  (...that and hopefully sell some CDs.)

1:00pm - It's GO TIME!!!

Using my own unique system of time estimation, (guessing) I had carefully calculated how much time I would have until I needed to return to my seat and beging lining up for my audition.

I guessed pretty correctly.  When I got back I had only about 40 minutes more of waiting to do.
I was surprisingly calm - mostly due to being so darn sleepy.  I actually managed to close my eyes again for another round of silent meditation.

When I came to, it was go time!  My section was prompted to get on its feet and we started snaking our way through the seating area and onto the floor...



1:30pm - You must be at least this tallented to ride The Ride to Stardom!!!

I took these photos as I was making my way to the judge's tables.  It was somewhere around this time that my stomach woke up along with the rest of my body and began doing flip flops.  Yeah, I was getting a tad nervous.

Once on the floor our tickets were checked and our release forms were collected.   The kids in the red shirts instructed us to line up 4x4 at the end of the barracades and stand behind a white duct tape line on the floor. 

(just like at Disneyland, wheee!!!)


Once in formation We were then directed to one of the 16 tables.  I was sent along with 3 others to what was technically Table 15 - (the one without the number - cheap bastards ran out of motherfuckin' signs.)

1:45 - My time to SHINE!!!

After all of the waiting and waiting and worrying and waiting - it was finally my time to shine!  I only had one shot at the brass ring - so I intended to make it count.  I was to sing last in our group of 4 so I did my best to stay focused and in the moment.  I wanted to enjoy this absurd experience as much as humanly possible.

When it was my turn I took a deep breath and stepped forward in front of the judge.  A rush of adrenaline propelled my voice to pump out of me twice as loud as normal.  I was gonna blow this fuckin' guy away!  And I think I did to be quite honest.  I also made eye contact with him the entire time and I thought I was a WINNER for sure!

THE MOMENT OF TRUTH - "I want to thank you guys for coming out today, but you're not the types we're looking for this season."

UGH!!!!!!!!!!!!

BLECH!!!!!!!!

ARGH!!!!!!!!!!

What the H?

Unfortunately, Third time was not  the charm after all.  I was crushed but by no means annihilated.  All in all it had been an okay experience this time.  I knew what I was getting myself into from my 2 previous experiences.  It was all going to be okay.

2:15pm - Let's go home!

After making the obligatory phone calls to my parents delivering the unfortunate news, I bucked up.  I hadn't won the lottery that day...but my time will come.  This world hasn't seen the last of Robin Rothman by a long shot!  and hey, now I could go buy Phillies tickets 'cause I was right across the street from Citizens Bank Park.  cool!

THE AFTERMATH...



Here I am - relieved it's all over (self portrait)



Even more relieved now that a kind gentleman on a passing bicyle has stopped to take my picture for me
(photo by anonymous cyclist)



THE...



END...

Yom Kippur initially seemed like it was going to be a little harder this year.   Not that it's my favorite of holidays, but sure - I look forward to a little spiritual cleansing every now and again!

For some reason this year, everywhere I turned it seemed like all of my friends had all kinds of really fun plans in store: birthday parties, bar-hopping, weekend getaways and other assorted activities - but none for me, thanks!  What was I going to be doing in the place of carousing with friends?  going back home to Philadelphia for a weekend of fasting and repenting for my sins.  that's what.  :-/

I hopped the NJ Transit and SEPTA trains back to Philly late last night and the good news was that I got quite a lot of self-reflecting and meditation done on the way.  This was to make up for the fact that I was missing Kol Nidre services.  (I also got a bit of game-playing done on my Treo.  that counts as meditation, right?)

When I arrived at my house, my parents were already asleep, so I retired fairly early as well.  Anything to keep my mind off of food since I was observing the fast as I have done every single Yom Kippur since the age of 12.  (What the hey, right?  Why break with tradition now when I've come this far?)

This morning I awoke fairly bright-eyed and bushy-tailed.  My first thought: "Hey, what's for breakfast?
...Oh right. never mind."  I was happy to discover however, that my parents had no intention of attending morning services.  (Trust me: morning services on an empty stomach is a real drag.)
Instead they opted to stay at home to pack up and organize a whole ton of clothing that they had been meaning to give away for a few months now.  This was our Mitzvah for the day - so I think that missing morning services was completely justified.

We did eventually make it over to Temple.  (Please, we're not complete heretics!)  Fortunately the afternoon service moved swiftly.   I even got to step out for a bit to make a charitable run over to the local Trader Joe's to pick up some more canned goods for the annual high holiday food drive.
*Yes, you read me  right.  I went food shopping whilst fasting.  Now is that will power or is that will power?!?*

I returned just in time for the concluding service which was then immediately followed by my personal favorite, a Havdalah service to bid farewell to the Sabbath.

Now, as I may have implied earlier in this entry, I am not the most religious of people by any means.  I consider myself more Jew-ish than Jewish.  By my own definition: I am more spiritual than religious.  As I've gotten older I've started to lose sight of the relevance of religion in the world.  It seems to divide people - violently in many cases, rather than bring them together.  And that is primarily why my reverence is failing.

This evening, however, as the Havdalah service got underway - the Rabbis called on all of the children in the congregation to assist in the lighting of the Havdalah candles.  Thirty-some children emerged from their seats and after a rousing final sounding of the Shofar,
the sanctuary lights were dimmed, candles were lit and blessings were sung.   Well, what a sight to see all of these children joined in song, their youthful faces illuminated by candle light.   Yeah, you get the picture.  it was really quite moving.

In that moment, I was reminded that religion can be beautiful when it is something that unites us.  I still haven't been completely converted by my own religion; but at least today I managed to find a new appreciation for it, while also absolving myself of this past year's sins.  (not counting of course the sin of doubting one's own religion.  is that considered a sin?  I sure hope not.  If so, I guess I'll have to atone for that one next year.)

L'Shana Tova!

Hey Live Journal - I'm just an another aspiring-to-be-paid actor trying to get a break.  I will do just about anything to get a leg up in this biz - (without literally putting my legs up, of course.)  but here is an example of where I draw the line...

Casting Networks, NY

 
RoleRole Type Gender/Age/EthnicitiesDescription/Note
Sally LeadFemale / 18 to 27 / All EthnicitiesSally is a shy young girl who's life is transformed by fate when she meets a lesbian from outer space. She becomes an honorary member of the group of alien women who kill men for pleasure.
MichelleFeaturedFemale / 18 to 27 / All EthnicitiesMichelle is a scathing indictment of college culture, the so called "sorority girl gone wild." She attempts to seduce a professor and meets her fate in a mad scientist's lab.
RebeccaFeaturedFemale / 18 to 28 / All EthnicitiesThe overbearing girlfriend of a detective hellbent on revenge, she's a pain in the ass who refuses to take anything lightly. She meets her end in a bloody mess thats the turning point of the film and sure to be a movie stealing scene.
 

really?  I think I'm gonna have to pass on this one LJ - (against my better judgment, of course)

This weekend my parents came in from out of town for a quick little visit.  They love coming up to New York every now and again to see the sights, take in some live theater, try out a new restaurant and nag and harass me about the goings on in my life.  ya know, that kind of thing.  (That last part is a given: they're parents after all.)

We went to this swell seafood restaurant in the Financial District last night - "Steamer's Landing" - right on the Hudson River, a stone's throw away from One World Financial Center. 



I have to confess that that's probably one of my favorite things about having my parents in from out of town: awesome, free dinners.  :)  We ordered a ton of food and for some reason whenever my parents are footin' the bill I can sure pack it away, boy!  Mussles, steamers, grilled salmon, yum, yum and YUM!

The view from the restaurant was also quite breath taking - however I only got to enjoy it for part of the evening because my contact lenses were burning my eyes so I had to take them out in the middle of the meal.  bummer.  Anyway, that place was good and I hope to return some time soon so that I can fully enjoy both the food and the view.


(I lifted this picture from another web page.  The view is even lovelier with the  buildings lit up at night.)

This afternoon we attended a Port Authority Picnic in Central Park.  That's right - a Port Authority Picnic.  Wow.  It was basically a bunch of engineers and they're families standing around eating hoagies (or sorry, Subs) and potato salad, talking about the same things that they talk about at work.  These guys have got to learn how to loosen up and have a good time.  I guess it was a good move on my dad's part to attend though.  Lucky for me I got to leave early to head downtown to my Musical Improv class.  That's what those engineers could use: a good hearty dose of Musical Improv!!!  I'll be sure to tell my dad to bring that up at the next Port Authority Picnic Planning Committee meeting. 

After an amazing class I got to head up town to see a rousing, over-the-top, all around magical production of Mary Poppin's.
Man, what a show!  I'm too sleepy to write a review of it right now - but golly gee whiz - those Disney folks sure know how to crank out the magic!  I mean, the sets and production design were enough to make anyone soil themselves with delight...and the actors filled  out every role splendidly.   For a wildly magical time - go see...

Speaking of Broadway shows I must get to bed to prepare for some auditions tomorrow and later this week.  Keep your fingers crossed for me Live Journal!

off I go! Spit Spot!

Hey Live Journal!  You know what today is?  Well I didn't...almost.

I am a bad Jew.  Bad Jew!  I had totally forgotten how early the high holidays come this year.  What a dope!

Anyway, I sorta had a pre-Rosh Hashannah dinner at home with my parents in Philly the other night.  does that count?  I don't have a Temple to go to in New York yet.  Yep, four years in New York without a Temple.  Oy vey!

What am I doing tonight?  Well, I'm going to audition for a children's theater troupe.  They're really funny and cute.  and I'm pretty sure that the Artistic Director is Jewish as well...

SO!

Let's just say that I am not being entirely sacreligious by not going to Temple tonight because I will be auditioning in a theater tonight - and everyone knows that the theater is MY Temple - and while we're at it - let's just say that the Jewish Artistic Director is the Rabbii leading the audition just as the Rabbii in the Temple leads the service.  AND Rosh Hashanna is basically like an audition anyway, right?  You have to be on your best behavior so that you can be inscribed in the Book of Life!  right? 

right?

eh...I'm sorry.  I'm a bad Jew. :(

I called my friend Michelle tonight for a little catch-up session like we usually do.  We chewed over the usual topics: friends, jobs, love life, etc.  and at one point in the conversation she asked, "well how was your day today?"  "It was okay," I replied.  "I actually felt a bit down, pretty depressed."  - "Oh, really? Why's that?" she asked.  "Well, I think it might have had a good deal to do with the anniversary."  "What anniversary?" she inquired.  "September 11th."  I said.

Now, granted I just learned that Michelle has recently started taking a light barbiturate to help her cope with severe migraine headaches that she's been having for the past couple of weeks - but still.  She had completely forgotten what this day was!  It had completely slipped her aching mind. 

I, on the other hand had not forgotten. 

Today, Tuesday, September 11th 2007 marks the 6 year anniversary of what was easily the most horrible and the most fortunate day of my life.  and there's not a day that goes by that I don't think about it. 

You see, my father is a survivor of Tower One. 

Six years ago, also on a Tuesday, I was asleep on the futon in my center city Philadelphia apartment when I awoke to the catastrophic news.  I had no idea what I was seeing on TV.  Was I awake?  Was it all a horrible dream? 

The time in the lower right corner of the TV read 6:03am - "Oh thank goodness!  My father isn't at work yet!"  Wrong.  that's Pacific Standard Time.  It's really 9:03am.  He's at work...in the building that's on fire!

It took a few minutes for me to get my bearings.  Wait, where am I really?  and what is REALLY going on?   Wake up Robin, seriously WAKE UP!!!

Katie Couric reported something about a guy calling from his office saying "We're ****ing dying up here!"  Well, that's not my dad's office.  It can't be.  This can't be happening for real.  What am I supposed to do?  Where is he???

I picked up my phone and frantically began dialing his cell phone and office number.  Nothing.  The cell kept going right to voice mail.  (Well, that's not a good sign.)  Where is he???

I tried to stay calm - I didn't want to call anyone else in my family because I didn't want to frighten them.  I left a few voice messages for my dad.  I'm sure that he's okay and he'll be calling me back any minute now.

The phone rings!  "Mom!  I know!  I know!  Have you heard from daddy?  Okay, call me when you hear from him!"  I was yelling in the phone, as though that would keep me from crying. 

I went back to the TV and watched the drama unfold in horror and disbelief.  What is happening?  Now the Pentagon has been hit?  What is HAPPENING??? 

I keep trying my father's cell to no avail.  His office number is now completely out of service.

"Where are you dad?"

The phone rings again.  "Hello?!?"  I shout.  My mother again:
"You heard from him?!?  He called you?!?!  Oh thank goodness!!!  Where is he???  Evacuating?  Okay!  Well call me when he gets out on the street!  Yes!  When he gets OUT!!!"

I hang up the phone - I fall to my knees.  relief like I've never known before washes over me.  and then I start to cry.  "Thank you!  Thank you G-d!"  I'm on my hands and knees at this point thanking heaven over and over again like some sort of religious radical. 
"He's okay." I say, "He's okay"  I repeat.
"Everything is going to be okay."

I keep reassuring myself of this every few minutes or so as I wipe the tears from my twisted face.  I return to the TV for a few moments.  Every channel is blasting coverage of the destruction from a slightly different vantage point. 

I'll call my grandmothers to pass the time...
First my father's mother:  "Hello!  Yes, I know!  He's fine!  He's on his way out of the tower.  Thank goodness!  He's alright!  We'll call you soon!"

Next my mother's mother:
"Yes, I know!  He's fine!  He's going to be okay!  He'll call us once he gets out onto the street.  No nothing yet. We'll call you...

The image of the Towers on TV abruptly changes.  The Tower on the left side of the screen crumbles into itself and falls out of sight. 

"I'll call you later."  I mumble to my grandmother.

What just happened?  What Tower was that?  Was it the North Tower, the South?  East?  West?  Why won't these fucking reporters get their fucking stories straight???  TOWER ONE or TOWER TWO???  What was that???

That can't be his Tower.  That can't be his.  He's got to be in the other one.  Yes, I think I remember his Tower is the other one.  The one on the right.  The right one. 

I call my father's cell again.  Damn!  Still no answer!!!

My mother calls - "Hello!  Um...yeah, one of the Towers just fell.  But I'm sure it's Tower Two.  It's not his, he's in Tower One.  They keep calling the Towers different things - but I know that he's in the other one.
Okay!  Call me when you hear from him!"

Okay, okay, okay.  Now I'm pacing back and forth like a rat in a cage.  What can I do?  What can I do?  I don't know what I can do.  What am I supposed to do?  Why is this happening???

I get down on my knees and pray.  And I pray harder and more intensely than I ever have in my entire life.  "Please G-d.  Please let my father be okay.  Please let him be okay.  Please bring him home to us.  Please G-d.  PLEASE."

I look back to the TV.  The other tower disappears.  Both are gone.  Dust and rubble.
Where is my father?

I remember my life flashing before my eyes:  my life without my father in it, that is:
He hasn't finished teaching me how to drive, what about my wedding day?  His grandchildren won't have a chance to know him... STOP!

Just stop.

The phone rings again. I am surrealy calm:   "Mom.  Both towers are gone.  Okay.  I'll meet you downstairs in 20 minutes."

I race into my room and throw some things into an overnight bag.  My mother was coming to pick me up and we would go home to the suburbs to wait.

Thank goodness for cellphones.  About 15 minutes later another call from my mother.  "He's out!!!"  She said.  "You just heard from him?"  I yelled.  "Yes, he's out.  He's safe."

When we reached our house, we were both emotionally exhausted and physically drained.  My grandparents were waiting for us in the driveway as we pulled up to the house.  Phone calls from neighbors and friends of the family poured in.  Finally, the call that I had been waiting for came through.  My father was at a family's friend's apartment where he was to spend the night because no one was permitted in or out of the city until the next day.

"Hello, Dad?"
"Hello Bird."
and then we cried. 

I think about how fortunate I am that my father's life was spared.   I think about how he was in the wrong place but somehow at the right time and he made it out!  He made it back Home. 

And sometimes it makes me think: why were we so fortunate?  (not lucky. I hate that word "luck")  His coming home was far greater than just having good luck.  My family was given an incredible gift that day.  We were spared a horrible fate:  A life without my father.  For this reason we were allowed to move on past this tragedy and return to a life of relative normalcy, while others who were not so fortunate are reminded of their loss every day.

So every day of my life, for the rest of my life I will continue to recognize this gift and be totally and utterly Grateful.


_________________________________________________________________________________________


This is my father's story of survival as only he can tell it.  This speech was written to commemorate the Five Year Anniversary of 9/11.

A Survivors Testimony

Background

I am an engineer employed since 1999 by the Port Authority of NY & NJ, the bi-state agency that owns and operates many transportation facilities in the New York Metropolitan area, including the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels, the Bayonne, George Washington and the Outerbridge Crossing Bridges, four airports (Newark Liberty International, John F. Kennedy International, LaGuardia and Teterboro), and several marine cargo terminals. They also operate the Port Authority- Trans Hudson (PATH) rapid transit system, and were the builders and owners of the World Trade Center.


On Tuesday, September 11, 2001, having just arrived at work on the 74th Floor of Tower One (the North Tower), I was starting my work day, when at 8:46 am, heard a loud noise somewhere nearby. This noise was followed by a sensation of the building swaying as though it was falling. This violent motion almost made me fall to the floor, but fortunately the building returned to an upright position. There were screams and confusion, with people running to the windows to witness the sight of papers flying everywhere like confetti, and then smoke and flames. After what seemed like several minutes, and the unmistakable odor of diesel fuel, there was a mass exodus to the fire stairs. A fairly orderly evacuation down 74 flights of stairs ensued, which lasted for about 50 minutes, during which time another explosion was heard. A co-worker who had the presence of mind to take a portable radio with him, was able to hear news reports of a second plane crashing into Tower Two. And of the plane that had crashed into the Pentagon. At this point, it was apparent that our concept of an accidental crash of a plane into our building was mistaken, and that we were under attack. Our fears were confirmed when we finally reached the ground floor, had to make our way through passageways littered with fallen sheet rock and leaking pipes. On the mezzanine we passed by large windows looking out onto the plaza. A scene of utter devastation appeared, complete with every imaginable horror I had never anticipated I would ever see- corpses, both whole and partial, spattered blood and other debris associated with loss of life. We were led down an escalator into the sub-level of the concourse with only emergency lights to light our way and fire sprinklers spraying us as we proceeded. We were led up another escalator and up to street level at the corner of Fulton and Church Streets. We were directed to walk quickly away from the buildings and not look back. It was impossible to avoid turning back to see the sight of the upper floors of the twin towers engulfed in flames and thick black smoke. It was also impossible to avoid the sight of pools of blood in the street, covered by newspaper to attempt to conceal the fact that people had landed there after jumping to their deaths to avoid the raging flames on the upper floors of the buildings.

And so I walked quickly away from Towers One and Two, smoldering remnants of an era of innocence. I came across several co-workers, including my boss, several blocks from Ground Zero, and we were just starting to discuss what to do next, when screams were heard followed by the words Run Tower Two is Falling! The sight of small bursts of flame, the crackling sounds, and the surreal appearance of a building collapsing into itself, followed by a cloud of dust are images that I will never forget. But even more unforgettable, was the thought, when the cloud of dust engulfed me despite my attempts to outrun it, that I was going to die then and there from suffocation.

But I survived that last onslaught, partially with the help of a tie used as a makeshift dust mask, and partially due to the dust cloud miraculously passing me by within a few seconds. That first breath, free of dust and the ashes of the dead, was a great relief. A block away, a street vendor was selling bottled water, just the thing that I needed to wash the dust out of my throat. I sat down on a park bench, dusted myself off the best I could, and rested. I had just escaped from a cataclysmic event by walking down 74 flights of stairs, walked five blocks to face a cloud of dust and ashes, and here I was sitting on a park bench. Wet from the fire sprinklers, coated with dust that had now become mud, I was a sight, but I was alive.

I sat for a while, collecting my thoughts and trying to decide what to do. There was no way to get home, so I needed a place to stay. I walked to the Soho office of my wifes college roommate, only to find that she was not at work. I then continued the two-mile walk to her Gramercy Park apartment where I stayed that night. To attempt to sleep, to make some sense of the days events. To wonder what happened to those I knew who worked in the buildings.

I returned home the next morning- a miraculous event in itself in light of what had occurred. Trains actually were running on schedule. A tearful reunion with my family was just what the doctor ordered- the start of a long recovery.


Five Years Later- So Now What?

So what am I left with, five years after this unforgettable event?

Certainly, very clear memories of the days prior to and the day of the events. I can still visualize the lobby of One World Trade Center that day, saying goodbye to my friend Peter Chirchirillo who worked on the 98th Floor, going through the security turnstiles, getting up from my desk to go to the fax machinethe explosionthe tower swayingthe smoke and the diesel fuel smell.descending the stairs with hundreds of people, the miraculous phone call to my wife from inside the stairwell telling her that I was on my way downstairsthe faces of the firemen going up as we went down. Yes, those firemen who thought they could save us, who paid the price for their devotion, are a large part of my lasting memory.

It is impossible to put this event completely in the past, thanks to the constant media attention. News stories on a daily basis on every aspect of the events leading to the event, the event and the aftermath of the event, are a reality. I have chosen not to watch many of these stories including The Path to 9/11, or the current movie, World Trade Center, as too sharp daggers in my already deep wounds. I was going to see World Trade Center, out of support for the heroes, but I decided that I dont need any reminders of what it was like that day

I have seen many news stories about the lasting remnants of that day the pain and sense of loss felt by losing a husband, father, mother, wife son or daughter so suddenly. It was a unique unexpected loss with no amount of preparation or warning. Not like an illness one can prepare for in terms of the ultimate end- just a family member leaving for work and never coming home. So many were affected that the sense of loss is collective and reaches into so many parts of our life. So many cultures, religious backgrounds, and age groups. We were equal opportunity victims.

In a New York Times article on the second anniversary, Christy Ferer, the wife of Neal Levin, the Executive Director of my agency who was killed on that day, stated, for me, the second anniversary of 9/11 is a catalyst to extricate myself from the hurt and negative energy that memories of the attack can generate. She has decided to move on and take the bull by the horns and turn tragedy into a positive outcome.

I recently saw a new story about a reunion of the babies of 9/11- babies born to mothers who were pregnant at the time of the tragedy. Five years later, as the babies grow, their mothers see the childrens resemblance to their late husbands. The babies are the lasting remembrance of those they had lost. There can be no greater memorial to our fallen. This also gives us the hope that life goes on, new life coming about despite the loss of the parent.

A daughter of one of the firefighters who was killed described her utter sorrow at her loss. She told of her despair after five years, that she cannot remember what her father looked like or the sound of his voice. She said that she has found that the only way to make herself happy was to make others happy. This is a great testimonial to the life of her father.

The daughter of Victor Saricini, the pilot of Flight 175 that was flown into Tower 2, is going to flight school. She says she feels her fathers presence in the cockpit when she flies and that she is continuing his legacy as a pilot.

As for me, I take this day as an opportunity not to dwell on the horrors of that day, but to be thankful for how truly lucky I am to have survived. I am here, able to continue to remember those people who died and what they could have done had they lived. I hope to take full advantage of those beautiful things in life, and to add beauty to the world rather than to dwell on the ugliness.

Since 9/11, I have had to deliver several technical presentations at regional and national conferences. At the start of each one I include a slide with the dedication, To the thousands of innocent people who died on September 11, 2001, simply pursuing their dreams to make a better life for themselves and their families, and to the hundreds of men and women who tried to save them. It is the most I can do to honor the memories of those who were not as fortunate as I was.

Using Christy Ferer and others as an inspiration, I continue to look for ways to give purpose to my life. I look for ways to comfort those in pain, to remember those we have lost and to honor their memory.

This is how we can truly honor the ones we have lost. Each one of them should be an inspiration to do good things. We have 2,749 reasons to make our world a better place in spite of all the evil that exists.

Well hello there!  I am on the brink of turning another year older and so I thought - why not do something productive like start a Live Journal.  Everybody's doing it - why don't you?  (is it a bad sign that I think of starting a Live Journal account as doing something productive with the last few days of 27-dom?)  I don't know.  I think it's pretty darn sweet. 

The week has gotten off to a bit of a sleepy start but I am in the office alone today so I can yawn all I want without the risk of sideways glances from boss lady.  Yes, I am here in the office while she is off gallivanting around in LA with the cast of "So You Think You Can Dance!"  Lucky her.

I was originally supposed to be Canada-bound this week...trip to the Toronto Improv Festival with my Team from a character-based improv show we did at UCB back in May.  Unfortunately our plans fell by the wayside and so regrettably I shan't be heading for the Canadian border this week.  :(

The crappier thing is that my birthday plans have also fallen by the wayside since I had anticipated being out of the country over my B-day.  So now I'll have to make due with some last-minute arrangements.  As of right now it looks like I'll be heading back to Philly on Friday for a steak dinner with my family and then back to the city Saturday evening for a Birthday Magnet Mixer with friends from the improv community.  Trying to decide whether or not I should get a keg...party patrons flock like moths to a flame when there's free alcohol involved.  ...well, it's true!
